elements.content: Through the powerful hydrothermal method, five rare-earth (Re = Dy, Gd, Ho, Pr, and Sm) three-dimensional (3D) cluster-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been synthesized, namely, [Dy­(L)­(H2O)­(DMF)] n (1), {[Gd­(L)­(H2O)­(DMF)]·DMF} n (2), {[Ho­(L)­(H2O)­(DMF)]·0.5DMF} n (3), {[Pr­(L)­(H2O)­(DMF)]·0.5DMF} n (4), and {[Sm­(L)­(H2O)1.55(DMF)0.45]·DMF} n (5; H3L = terphenyl-3,4″,5-tricarboxylic acid), which have been determined by single crystal X-ray analyses and PXRD characterization. Structural analyses reveal that, in 1–5, these L3– ligands are linked by five different rare-earth centers, forming the iso-structural nanoporous frameworks. PXRD patterns of bulky samples 1–5 also are consistent with theoretical PXRD patterns confirming their purity. Solid state photoluminesce of free H3L and 1–5 at room temperature also has been investigated indicating strong ligand-based emissions. Besides these, fluorescent dye Rhodamine B (RhB) can be introduced into MOF1 forming the composite material RhB@MOF1 with a high quantum yield of 35%. It is noted that, through deliberately tuning the morphologies of nanoparticle MOF1 under different ultrasonic conditions, RhB@MOF1 can be utilized as the first ratiometric fluorescent sensor to effectively discriminate l- and d-lysine from other amino acid molecules with high K sv values and low LOD values. On the other hand, 2 was for the first time to be utilized as an excellent bifunctional MOFs-based sensing platform to detect insulin and Al3+ with a low detection limit in the human serum solution.

elements.content: Lysine, a precursor for carnitine biosynthesis, has a key effect in β-oxidation of fatty acids. Lysine is also considered to be involved in decomposition and metabolism and then results in irreversible α-aminoadipate formation via a saccharopine pathway. Superfluous lysine also may lead to congenital metabolic disorders such as ascystinuria or hyperlysinemia in plasma and urine. Studies have also shown that it can improve the immune system and protect against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. Some studies suggest that lysine may also help prevent bone loss, because it helps body tissues absorb calcium. Symptoms of lysine deficiency include nausea, weakness, fatigue, dizziness, vomiting, slow development, anemia, loss of appetite, etc. However, there are only a few reports about detecting lysine. The design of a sensitive analytical method for the detection of lysine still remains a meaningful challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lysine, a precursor for carnitine biosynthesis, has a key effect in β-oxidation of fatty acids. Lysine is also considered to be involved in decomposition and metabolism and then results in irreversible α-aminoadipate formation via a saccharopine pathway. Superfluous lysine also may lead to congenital metabolic disorders such as ascystinuria or hyperlysinemia in plasma and urine. Studies have also shown that it can improve the immune system and protect against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. Some studies suggest that lysine may also help prevent bone loss, because it helps body tissues absorb calcium. Symptoms of lysine deficiency include nausea, weakness, fatigue, dizziness, vomiting, slow development, anemia, loss of appetite, etc. However, there are only a few reports about detecting lysine. The design of a sensitive analytical method for the detection of lysine still remains a meaningful challenge.

elements.content: With the improvement of living standards, diabetes mellitus is considered a nightmare widespread among patients. To date, approximately 400 million people globally suffer from diabetes. Diabetes often becomes serious when there is little insulin in the pancreas or when insulin cannot be effectively utilized by the human body. Hence, insulin level is essential for diagnosis of diabetes. Aptamers often are employed as single-stranded DNA or RNA chains, which can recognize and bind target small molecules such as insulin by means of their three-dimensional folding. On the other hand, aluminum was quite important for industry development; however, patients with alzheimer’s disease or mental disorders have more than 10–30 times greater aluminum concentration in their brains than normal people. Further study confirmed that high aluminum content in food will cause a person’s early aging, which also can further cause brain nerve degeneration, memory loss, intelligence, and even senile dementia. When the amount of aluminum accumulation in the body exceeds 5–16 times that of the normal level, it can inhibit the absorption of phosphorus in the intestine and interfere with the normal calcium and phosphorus metabolism in the body. According to a previous report, long-term exposure to a high concentration of Al3+ pollution in the living environment may cause internal environmental changes and result in metabolic dysfunction. Al3+ also affects blood glucose levels in the body. Thus far, reports about the detection of insulin and Al3+ in the human serum solution were scarce. Therefore, the design of a highly efficient, convenient luminescent sensing platform to detect insulin and Al3+ is very essential.

elements.content: In comparison with other analytical methods, such as atomic absorption spectrometry, gas chromatography, and ion mobility spectrometry, the fluorescence technique can afford facile, sensitive, and fast assays and would likely be preferred if available. Among numerous reported luminescent materials, lanthanide-based metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) recently bloomed out as promising chemical sensors because they can conveniently induce luminescence such as the “antenna effect,” advantages in various structural and functional components and many different detecting mechanisms. In comparison with other nanometer materials such as gold nanoparticles, graphene oxide (GO), single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), and carbon nanoparticles, lanthanide-based MOFs as a sensing platform have aroused enormous attention due to their controllable size and porosity, flexible and variable structure, specific functional groups, and metal site. For example, Cheng et al. designed a water stable luminescent lanthanide coordination complex as a sensor utilized in the rapid detection of the biomarkers for carcinoid tumors. Shi and Wang’s group also have reported a lanthanide coordination complex for the highly sensitive detection of polychloriznated benzenes, which are persistent organic pollutants and can generate permanent damage to human health.

elements.content: Fluorescent dyes can be utilized as an ideal candidate for detection work because they possess high quantum yield and excellent optical and electronic properties. Therefore, it will be desirable to combine luminescent MOFs with fluorescent dyes to design composites materials for fluorescence applications. In addition, in the Dye@MOF self-calibration system, their dual-emission centers can be utilized as the ratiometric fluorescent probe. By measuring and calculating linear relation between their intensity ratio and concentration, the object analysts can be quantitatively determined. The simultaneous determination of two photoluminescent emissions at different wavelengths can form a built-in self-calibration for environmental analysts. For example, previously, Wu et al. established a luminescent Rho@CZJ-3 platform for the fingerprint sensing of different VOMs (volatile organic molecules) based on dual emission centers. Su and Lan’s group used the Rh6@NENU-519 as a dual-emitting fluorescent sensor for sensing different explosives. Therefore, Dye@MOF composites have aroused numerous scientists’ attentions. However, the design of an ideal dual responsive ratiometric sensor for the detection of biological small molecules was still scarcely reported and remains a great challenge.

elements.content: We also are interested in the construction of these novel coordination frameworks, which can be utilized as functional materials with intriguing magnetic and photoluminescent properties. In this work, five lanthanide isostructural metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been synthesized. In 1–5, these L3– ligands are linked via lanthanide centers, forming the nanoporous coordination frameworks. PXRD patterns of bulky samples 1–5 also are well consistent with theoretical patterns confirming the pure samples. 1 and 2 were measured by variable temperature direct current (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurement exhibiting weak antiferro-magnetic interactions between neighboring rare-earth centers. Because H3L contains highly conjugated aromatic rings of triphenyl moieties, 1–5 can have good luminescent properties, which are also revealed by solid fluorescence spectra. 1 can be designed to combine Rhodamine B (RhB) to form a unique ratiometric fluorescent sensor RhB@MOF1 with high quantum yield (35%). For the first time, RhB@MOF1 as a MOFs-based ratiometric fluorescent sensor was utilized to detect lysine. In addition, it can further distinguish l- and d-lysine by different K sv values in the complex solutions. On the other hand, 1 also can be synthesized by the ultrasonic synthetic method conveniently; the relationship between the particle size of 1 and the fluorescence quenching effect is also discussed, which can find the optimum particle size of 1 to form the composite material RhB@MOF1. On the other hand, MOF2 was utilized to detect insulin and Al3+. The photoluminescent experiment reveals that 2 can be utilized as a first example of a bifunctional MOFs-based sensing platform to detect insulin and Al3+ via aptamer (FAM-P) with high sensitivity.

elements.content: The preparation of the H3L ligand was carried out by reported methods. The DNA sequence utilized was prepared by Shanghai Sangon Biotechnology Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the other reagents were used without further purification and were commercially purchased and utilized. A PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer is ulitized to determine carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen microanalyses. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was characterized by a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer utilizing Cu Kα radiation. FT-IR spectra (4000–500 cm–1) were performed by utilizing a NICOLET 6700 FT-IR spectroscope with KBr pellets (NICOLET, USA). Ultrasonic preparation was performed using a SB-100DT Ultrasonic bath (XJ Biotechnology Instrument, Zhe Jiang, China). PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer was utilized to recording ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) adsorption spectra. Emission fluorescence spectra were recorded on an RF-5301 spectrophotometer (Daojin, Japan). The photoluminescent lifetime, quantum yield, and solid fluorescent spectrum were performed using a Fluorolog-3, Horiba Jobin Yvon (USA). The different morphologies of nanoparticle 1 were determined with both a Nova-Nano 230 scanning electron microscope (SEM; FEI instrument, USA) with gold coating and a Tecnai G2 F20 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM; FEI instrument, USA). The zeta potential measurements were performed on a Nano-ZS, Worcestershire (Malvern, UK). Fluorescent DNA images were gained on a Leica SP8 confocal microscope (Leica, Germany) with a 405 nm laser as the excitation source.
elements.clean_text:
General Methods

The preparation of the H3L ligand was carried out by reported methods. The DNA sequence utilized was prepared by Shanghai Sangon Biotechnology Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the other reagents were used without further purification and were commercially purchased and utilized. A PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer is ulitized to determine carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen microanalyses. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was characterized by a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer utilizing Cu Kα radiation. FT-IR spectra (4000-500 cm-1) were performed by utilizing a NICOLET 6700 FT-IR spectroscope with KBr pellets (NICOLET, USA). Ultrasonic preparation was performed using a SB-100DT Ultrasonic bath (XJ Biotechnology Instrument, Zhe Jiang, China). PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer was utilized to recording ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) adsorption spectra. Emission fluorescence spectra were recorded on an RF-5301 spectrophotometer (Daojin, Japan). The photoluminescent lifetime, quantum yield, and solid fluorescent spectrum were performed using a Fluorolog-3, Horiba Jobin Yvon (USA). The different morphologies of nanoparticle 1 were determined with both a Nova-Nano 230 scanning electron microscope (SEM; FEI instrument, USA) with gold coating and a Tecnai G2 F20 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM; FEI instrument, USA). The zeta potential measurements were performed on a Nano-ZS, Worcestershire (Malvern, UK). Fluorescent DNA images were gained on a Leica SP8 confocal microscope (Leica, Germany) with a 405 nm laser as the excitation source.

elements.content:
FAM-P: 5′-GGTGGTGGGG­GGGGTTGGTA­GGGTGTCTTC-3′-FAM

Experimental SectionPreparation of [Dy­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of dysprosium acetate (25.7 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added into the mixture of DMF (4 mL) and H2O (2 mL). The mixed solutions were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon reactor; after the reaction mixture had been heated at 120 °C for 3 days and then cooled to ambient temperature after 20 h, colorless bulky crystals of 1 were isolated in 64% yield based on the H3L ligand. Elemental analysis found (%) for C24H20DyNO8: C, 46.6; H, 3.16; N, 1.98. Calcd: C, 47.03; H, 3.29; N, 2.28. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3401 (w), 1669 (s), 1628 (m), 1585 (w), 1534 (m), 1418 (m), 1382 (w), 1299 (w), and 780 (w).

elements.content: A mixture of dysprosium acetate (414 mg, 1 mmol) and H3L (256 mg, 1 mmol) was added into the mixture of DMF (40 mL) and H2O (20 mL). The resulting mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath for 80 min and under 100 W of power. The resulting precipitates were washed with DMF and H2O three times. Sample 1 was isolated in 52% yield based on H3L yield. Elemental analysis found (%) for C24H20DyNO8: C, 45.6; H, 2.96; N, 1.98. Calcd: C, 47.03; H, 3.29; N, 2.28.

Preparation of [Dy(L)(H2O)(DMF)] n  (1) in Sonochemical Process

A mixture of dysprosium acetate (414 mg, 1 mmol) and H3L (256 mg, 1 mmol) was added into the mixture of DMF (40 mL) and H2O (20 mL). The resulting mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath for 80 min and under 100 W of power. The resulting precipitates were washed with DMF and H2O three times. Sample 1 was isolated in 52% yield based on H3L yield. Elemental analysis found (%) for C24H20DyNO8: C, 45.6; H, 2.96; N, 1.98. Calcd: C, 47.03; H, 3.29; N, 2.28.

elements.content: In this work, 2 mg of MOF1 prepared under ultrasonic conditions (100 W, 80 min, 1 mM) was added into 10 mL of 20 mg/L RhB water solution. The resulting mixed solutions were stirred for 30 mintues and then heated to 60 °C in 24 h; then they were cooled down to ambient temperature. The solid samples can be obtained by centrifugation for 10 min at 8000 rpm, extensive washing with DMF three times, and then removal of the liquid supernatant and vacuum drying.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of RhB@MOF1

In this work, 2 mg of MOF1 prepared under ultrasonic conditions (100 W, 80 min, 1 mM) was added into 10 mL of 20 mg/L RhB water solution. The resulting mixed solutions were stirred for 30 mintues and then heated to 60 °C in 24 h; then they were cooled down to ambient temperature. The solid samples can be obtained by centrifugation for 10 min at 8000 rpm, extensive washing with DMF three times, and then removal of the liquid supernatant and vacuum drying.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for 1, 3, and 5 were performed on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer utilizing graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction intensities for 2 and 4 were performed utilizing graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Lorentz polarization, the ω–φ scanning method, and absorption corrections were utilized. The structures were analyzed by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares method utilizing the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. Organic hydrogen atoms were defined geometrically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were utilized, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Crystallographic data and refinement details for 1–5 were summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S1, and selected hydrogen bonds lengths [Å] and angles [deg] are listed in Table S2, which were calculated with the program PLATON. X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for 1, 3, and 5 were performed on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer utilizing graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction intensities for 2 and 4 were performed utilizing graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Lorentz polarization, the ω-φ scanning method, and absorption corrections were utilized. The structures were analyzed by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares method utilizing the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. Organic hydrogen atoms were defined geometrically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were utilized, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Crystallographic data and refinement details for 1-5 were summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S1, and selected hydrogen bonds lengths [Å] and angles [deg] are listed in Table S2, which were calculated with the program PLATON. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that all the cluster-based coordination frameworks 1–5 belong to the monoclinic system with a C 2/c space group. Because 1–5 have iso-structural 3D coordination frameworks, therefore, only the structure of MOF1 is described herein representatively. The fundamental structural unit of MOF1 contains one DyIII center (Dy1), one full depronated L3–, one terminal coordinated water molecule (O7), and one terminal coordinated DMF (O8). Selected bond lengths and angles of 1–5 were summarized in Table S1. The bond length Dy–O ranges from 2.691 to 2.319 Å, and the bond O–Dy–O angle ranges from 67.24° to 149°. These coordinated waters were involved in C–H···O hydrogen bonds (C–H···O angle was 136°). All the Re–O coordination bonds and angles all fall into the normal range. In 1–5, with the increase of atomic number from Pr-MOF (2.52 Å) to Ho-MOF (2.41 Å), the average Re–O bond lengths decreased gradually, indicating that there was existence of a lanthanide contraction effect.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions of Coordination Frameworks 1-5 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that all the cluster-based coordination frameworks 1-5 belong to the monoclinic system with a C 2/c space group. Because 1-5 have iso-structural 3D coordination frameworks, therefore, only the structure of MOF1 is described herein representatively. The fundamental structural unit of MOF1 contains one DyIII center (Dy1), one full depronated L3-, one terminal coordinated water molecule (O7), and one terminal coordinated DMF (O8). Selected bond lengths and angles of 1-5 were summarized in Table S1. The bond length Dy-O ranges from 2.691 to 2.319 Å, and the bond O-Dy-O angle ranges from 67.24° to 149°. These coordinated waters were involved in C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (C-H⋅⋅⋅O angle was 136°). All the Re-O coordination bonds and angles all fall into the normal range. In 1-5, with the increase of atomic number from Pr-MOF (2.52 Å) to Ho-MOF (2.41 Å), the average Re-O bond lengths decreased gradually, indicating that there was existence of a lanthanide contraction effect.

elements.content: As depicted in , each central DyIII ion (Dy1) is nine-coordinated by seven O atoms (O1, O1A, O2A, O3, O4, O5, O6) from L3–, one terminal coordinated H2O (O7), and one terminal coordinated DMF oxygen atom (O8). It is noted that Dy1 and Dy1A are linked via carboxylate oxygen atoms forming dinuclear Dy2O2 clusters as secondary building blocks (SBUS). On the other hand, each full deprotonated L3– links three neighboring dinuclear DyIII SBUS with muti-dentate bridging mode, which ultimately constructs the 3D cluster-based nanoporous coordination framework 1 (). The Re···Re separation of 16.4674(9) Å × 9.0591(4) Å (for 1), 12.767­(1) Å × 9.0326 (5) Å (for 2), 12.9661(10) Å × 8.8252(5) Å (for 3), 16.5876 (4) Å × 9.2257(8) Å (for 4), and 17.0677(1) Å × 8.7125(7) Å (for 5) can be observed along the crystallographic c axis, respectively, in which free solvent molecules are located. The porous percentage in MOFs 1–5 was calculated with the Platon program; the calculated results were 31.5%, 33.5%, 30.6%, 32.2%, and 28.7% solvent accessible voids in 1–5, respectively. On the other hand, these carbon and oxygen atoms from L3– and water were also involved in C–H···O hydrogen bonds (Table S2). Such weak interactions also played a crucial role in stabilizing the whole network.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of MOFs 1–5 are also determined at ambient temperature to measure the sample’s phase purity. Most peak positions in simulated and experimental patterns are consistent with each other. The intensity dissimilarities may be correlated with the preferred orientation of crystalline powder samples (). The thermogravimetric decay analysis (TGA) curve of MOFs 1–5 also has been recorded (Figure S1). The weight losses of MOFs 1–5 material ranging from 30 to 200 °C are 14.66 wt %, 23 wt %, 19.01 wt %, 17.03 wt %, and 18.9 wt %, respectively, which should be attributed to the weight loss for coordination water, free DMF, and coordination DMF molecules. These results can be in good agreement with the calculated values (14.86 wt %, 22.6 wt %, 20.7 wt %, 17.8 wt %, 18.1 wt %, respectively).

The weight losses of MOFs 1-5 material ranging from 30 to 200 °C are 14.66 wt %, 23 wt %, 19.01 wt %, 17.03 wt %, and 18.9 wt %, respectively, which should be attributed to the weight loss for coordination water, free DMF, and coordination DMF molecules. elements.content: Fluorescent MOFs have received great interest because of their numerous applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Photoluminescence properties of free H3L and MOFs 1–5 were performed in the solid state at ambient temperature (). The free H3L demonstrates an intense emission located between 340 and 600 nm (λmax = 375 nm upon excitation at 290 nm), which should originate from the large conjugate triphenyl aromatic moieties in H3L. In comparison to those of free H3L ligands, solid-state photoluminescent peaks for MOFs 1–5 are almost located at the same position, which should be ligand-based photoluminescence emissions. It is noted that the typical rare-earth (Re = Dy, Gd, Ho, Pr, and Sm) characteristic peaks are not observed, which may be correlated with strong ligand-based photoluminesce. A slight blue shift of emission bands for 1, 3, and 5 can be observed, which may be ascribed to the coordination action of the ligand to central lanthanide ions.

elements.content: With a large unquenched orbital angular momentum, lanthanide (Ln) ions can bring large and anisotropic magnetic moments to the system. The intrinsic large spin–orbit coupling and the ligand field interaction correlated with lanthanide ions make them appealing. In this work, DyIII and GdIII coordination polymers 1 and 2 have been determined by 2–300 K variable temperature magnetic measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Variable Temperature Direct Current (2-300 K) Magnetic Susceptibility Measurement of 1 and 2 

With a large unquenched orbital angular momentum, lanthanide (Ln) ions can bring large and anisotropic magnetic moments to the system. The intrinsic large spin-orbit coupling and the ligand field interaction correlated with lanthanide ions make them appealing. In this work, DyIII and GdIII coordination polymers 1 and 2 have been determined by 2-300 K variable temperature magnetic measurement.

elements.content: MOF1 (29.78 mg ground samples) has been investigated by variable temperature (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibility, with an applied DC field of 1000 Oe. For MOF1 at 300 K, the χM T value was 12.84 cm3 K mol–1 (Figure S2a). The observed χM T value is slightly lower than the expected theotetrical value (χM T = 14.17 cm3 K mol–1), which may be ascribed to the combined effect of magnetic anisotropy, intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction, dipolar interaction, etc. When the temperature decreases, the χM T value gradually decreases to 10.75 cm3K mol–1 at 20 K, and then decreases to a value of 9.33 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. These features indicate the presence of weak antiferro-magnetic interactions between neighboring Dy­(III) ions. According to the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ), the linear fit gave values of C = 12.85 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −3.98 K, where C and θ are the Curie constant and the Weiss temperature, respectively.
elements.clean_text: MOF1 (29.78 mg ground samples) has been investigated by variable temperature (2-300 K) magnetic susceptibility, with an applied DC field of 1000 Oe. For MOF1 at 300 K, the χM T value was 12.84 cm3 K mol-1 (Figure S2a). The observed χM T value is slightly lower than the expected theotetrical value (χM T = 14.17 cm3 K mol-1), which may be ascribed to the combined effect of magnetic anisotropy, intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction, dipolar interaction, etc. When the temperature decreases, the χM T value gradually decreases to 10.75 cm3K mol-1 at 20 K, and then decreases to a value of 9.33 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. These features indicate the presence of weak antiferro-magnetic interactions between neighboring Dy(III) ions. According to the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ), the linear fit gave values of C = 12.85 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -3.98 K, where C and θ are the Curie constant and the Weiss temperature, respectively.

elements.content: Variable temperature (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibility experiments were also determined on the polycrystalline samples of MOF2. The χM T values at room temperature are slightly larger than the theoretical χM T values (7.88 cm3 K mol–1). When the temperature decreases, the χM T value gradually decreases to 7.79 cm3 mol–1 K at 20 K and then sharply decreases to 7.11 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K (Figure S2b). This phenomenon also can be correlated with the large unquenched orbital angular momentum of Gd3+. According to the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), gave values of C = 8.38 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −1.95 K, where C and θ are the Curie constant and the Weiss temperature, respectively. The θ value also represents the presence of weak antiferro-magnetic interaction between GdIII ions. There were weak magnetic interactions in multinuclear MOFs 1 and 2, which should be attributed to the shielding effects of the outer 5d and 6s shells to the inner contracted 4f orbitals.

elements.content: To explore the ways of improving higher sensitivity of MOFs-based sensors, an ultrasonic synthetic method was often adopted. Therefore, the relationship between different ultrasonic time, power, initial concentrations, and morphology variations were investigated: (1) As shown in a and b, under ultrasound irradiation, the particle sizes of 1 were smaller and more dispersed than samples synthesized under the hydrothermal method. (2) As shown in c and d, when the ultrasonic power increases from 70 to 100 W, the submicron samples’ size decreases from around 7.5 to 0.7 nm and becomes more dispersed. (3) As shown in e and f, under the same ultrasonic power and time (100 W, 80 min), when initial concentrations have been changed (from 1 to 0.5 mM), SEM images reveal that uniform plate-like morphology can be obtained by decreasing of the initial concentration of reagents. (4) As shown in g–i, when the ultrasonic power (70 W) is fixed, with increasing ultrasonic time (40, 60, and 80 min), the particles’ sizes (2.7, 1.9, and 0.4 μm) gradually become smaller and their dispersity wider.
elements.clean_text:
Tuning Morphology of MOF1 by Ultrasonic Method

To explore the ways of improving higher sensitivity of MOFs-based sensors, an ultrasonic synthetic method was often adopted. Therefore, the relationship between different ultrasonic time, power, initial concentrations, and morphology variations were investigated: (1) As shown in a and b, under ultrasound irradiation, the particle sizes of 1 were smaller and more dispersed than samples synthesized under the hydrothermal method. (2) As shown in c and d, when the ultrasonic power increases from 70 to 100 W, the submicron samples' size decreases from around 7.5 to 0.7 nm and becomes more dispersed. (3) As shown in e and f, under the same ultrasonic power and time (100 W, 80 min), when initial concentrations have been changed (from 1 to 0.5 mM), SEM images reveal that uniform plate-like morphology can be obtained by decreasing of the initial concentration of reagents. (4) As shown in g-i, when the ultrasonic power (70 W) is fixed, with increasing ultrasonic time (40, 60, and 80 min), the particles' sizes (2.7, 1.9, and 0.4 μm) gradually become smaller and their dispersity wider.

elements.content: Overall, by adjusting the ultrasonic irradiation time, power, and initial concentration, the morphologies of nanoporous MOF1 can be deliberately tuned. When ultrasonic time (80 min), ultrasonic power (100 W), and double initial concentration (0.1 mM) are used, the more micro- and uniform distributed nanoparticles sizes of MOF1 can be synthesized, which also be benefit to form more dispersible nanoparticles in aqueous solution for detection.

elements.content: From the TEM images (), both MOF1’s nanoporous structures under the ultrasonic and hydrothermal conditions can be observed. Additionally, nanoporous sample 1 under the ultrasonic method can have more and larger porous size than sample 1 synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Therefore, in the preparation process of the composite material RhB@MOF1, nanoporous sample 1 under the ultrasound method (100 W, 80 min, 1 mM) is used, which can be more conducive to encapsulating rhodamine.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S3, after the as-synthesized MOF1 was heated at 60 °C under a vacuum for 12 h, PXRD analysis of the sample showed that the sharp diffraction peaks almost disappear. This result suggests that MOF1 lost its long-range order upon removal of the included solvent molecules. However, the sharp diffraction peaks of PXRD can be restored by immersion in the mother solution for 72 h. These results suggest that the structure of MOF1 is flexible and reversible depending upon the solvent guests; this experimental result also is similar to Wu’s group’s work, in which the structure of CZJ-3 is also flexible and reversible depending upon the solvent guests. Therefore, such properties prevent the evaporated MOF1 from taking up gas molecules as revealed by the gas adsorption experiments (Figure S4). To value MOF1’s absorption toward RhB molecules, a dye-uptake assay was employed. By soaking a sample of MOF1 (channel size of ca. 9.1 Å × 16.5 Å, vacant space in 1 is about 31.5%) in the Rhodamine B solution (Figure S5; cross dimensions of ca. 6.43 × 12.7 × 15.5 Å3) for 24 h at room temperature, the dye was almost fully absorbed by MOF1, as determined by UV/vis absorption spectroscopy, and the dye-uptake was 0.28 wt % (Figures S6 and S7). Further, the sorption abilities of MOF1 and RhB@MOF1 for phenylcarbinol were also investigated, by immersing samples of MOF1 and RhB@MOF1 in phenylcarbinol solvents for 12 h at room temperature to study their guest inclusion properties. UV/vis analysis indicates that the activated ones readily take up 2.2 and 0.7 molecules of phenylcarbinol per formula unit of MOF1 and RhB@MOF1, respectively (Figure S8). RhB@MOF1 is very stable, and the included Rhodamine B molecules cannot leak into solution during the absorption of different small solvent molecules, as determined by UV/vis absorption spectroscopy.

elements.content: In order to further confirm the effective combination between RhB and MOF1 in RhB@MOF1, a solid fluorescent spectrum for RhB@MOF1 and the simple mixture of RhB and MOF1 has been recorded. As shown in a, RhB@MOF1 exhibits an intense dual emission center between 350 and 690 nm (λmax = 375 nm for 1, λmax = 620 nm for RhB, upon excitation at 290 nm); both 1 and RhB’s emission peaks can be observed. However, the simple mixture of RhB and 1’s spectrum can be only observed by 1’s emission peak. The experimental results demonstrate that the RhB molecules should be located in the pores of 1 and well isolated by the pore confinement effect. This advantageous structure suppressed the nonradiative energy transfer process, which commonly exists in agglomerate dyes and causes quenching of the dye emission. This experimental phenomenon was also similar to Zhou’s recently reported work; the hybrid material, namely Rh101@UIO-67, simultaneously exhibits two characteristic peaks in a solid fluorescent spectrum, while the simple mixture of RhB and UIO-67 only exhibits UIO-67’s characteristic peak. This result also indicates that RhB has been successfully combined by MOF1 forming the RhB@MOF1 composite material.

elements.content: The as-synthesized PXRD patterns of RhB@MOF1 and as-simulated theoretical PXRD ones were in good agreement, indicating that the structure of the framework remains unchanged when RhB is introduced into the coordination framework 1. Thermogravimetric decay analysis (TGA) curves of MOF1 and RhB@MOF1 are also recorded (c). The weight loss of material MOF1 ranging from 30 to 200 °C is 14.66 wt %, which should be attributed to coordinated water and DMF’s evaporation. The result can be good agreement with the calculated value (14.86 wt %). However, for the thermal cure of RhB@MOF1, the weight loss of RhB@MOF1 in the range of 30 to 200 °C is slightly lower than that of MOF1; the result may be ascribed to DMF and water molecules being partially replaced by RhB in RhB@MOF1.

elements.content: Bright fluorogenic rhodamine can be used as excellent photoluminescent candidate material because the RhB acceptor is in its inactivated closed-ring form in the neutral and alkaline environments; the donors are not electronically conjugated with it. Upon activation such as detection of an analyte, spiro-ring opening occurs on the RhB, which further leads to a fluorescence intensity increase. The dye emission can be also effectively sensitized by the framework linkers through fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). Therefore, a dye@MOF ratiometric probe with dual emission peaks can construct the self-calibration system based on the two emission bands from MOF and dye molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Ratiometric Fluorescent Sensing for Lysine by RhB@MOF1

Bright fluorogenic rhodamine can be used as excellent photoluminescent candidate material because the RhB acceptor is in its inactivated closed-ring form in the neutral and alkaline environments; the donors are not electronically conjugated with it. Upon activation such as detection of an analyte, spiro-ring opening occurs on the RhB, which further leads to a fluorescence intensity increase. The dye emission can be also effectively sensitized by the framework linkers through fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). Therefore, a dye@MOF ratiometric probe with dual emission peaks can construct the self-calibration system based on the two emission bands from MOF and dye molecules.

elements.content: To detect ratiometric probe application in the selective detection of amino acid molecules, the chemical resistance samples of RhB@MOF1 (10 mg) were ground, ultrasonicated for 5 min, and prepared as water suspension samples (0.1 g/L, 3 mL, water solution). Each suspension contains 2 μM of different amino acids solution (l-lysine, d-lysine, l-valine, l-cysteine, creatine, l-alanine, l-histidine, l-methionine, nicotinamide, d-cystqeine, l-serine, water solution). It is noted that the RhB@MOF1’s emission intensities were largely associated with the addition of diverse amino acids molecules (). Only l-lysine and d-lysine can influence RhB@MOF1’s emission intensities distinctly. It means that with the addition of l-,d-lysine solution, the photoluminescent emission bands centered at 372 nm gradually increased; meanwhile the emission centered at 581 nm gradually decreased, while other analyses had no obvious effect on the photoluminescent emission of RhB@MOF1.

elements.content: The experimental results show RhB@MOF1 can have a dipartite effect toward l-lysine and d-lysine in other amino acids. For RhB@MOF1, the emission ratio (I 372nm/I 581nm) displayed a strong linear relationship toward l-lysine and d-lysine in the range from 0 to 0.4 μM (a,b); corresponding fitting equations are observed as I 372nm/I 580nm = 1.82872 + 1.67615*­[l-lysine], R 2 = 0.98203, I 372nm/I 580nm = 1.58438 + 5.75246*­[d-lysine], R 2 = 0.98205. The K sv value was 1.67 × 106 [M]−1 for l-lysine (R 2 = 0.98203), while the K sv value was 5.75 × 106 [M]−1 for d-lysine (R 2 = 0.98205). The detection limit LOD = 3S 0/S (S/N = 3) can be used to determine the l-lysine and d-lysine analytical techniques’ sensitivity. According to Das et al.’s previous work, a pyrene excimer, namely BAPA, can be used as a ratiometric sensor for lysine; the detection limit was 5 × 10–8 μM, while RhB@MOF1 has a detection limit of 0.024 μM and 0.007 μM for l- and d-lysine, respectively, which can compare with the previous report and also indicate the RhB@MOF1’s high sensitivity. After every 14 s, the fluorescent intensity of 1 increases more than the initial fluorescent intensity (emission at 372 nm), suggesting that RhB@MOF1 can detect in real-time l-lysine (Figure S9a). The quantum yield of RhB@MOF1 was 35%, which was also higher than other materials. The analytic method’s high sensitivity was manifested by these experimental results.

elements.content: Further, to investigate the RhB@MOF1 fluorescence effect response to the mixed solutions containing l- and d-lysine simultaneously, different molar ratios for l- and d-lysine (1:1, 1:2, and 1:3 in the complex solutions) were also used. The concentration ranges of the solution vary from 0 to 0.4 μM; three complex solutions’ linear correlations can be observed. It is interesting to note that the slope of these lines can be influenced by different molar ratios of l- and d-lysine; with increasing the molar ratios of d-lysine in the mixed solution, the K sv values increase gradually (c). For the first time, RhB@MOF1 also represents the MOFs-based sensors for real-time ratiometric fluorescent sensors to distinguish l- and d-lysine by different photoluminescent increasing effects. In comparison with the quenching effect of other samples synthesized under ultrasound methods toward d-lysine (emission located at 581 nm), nanoparticles of 1 prepared using the ultrasonic method (100 W, 80 min, 1 mM) can be utilized as more convenient and the most effective fluorescence sensor for discriminating lysine with the highest K sv value ().

elements.content: On the basis of the above RhB@MOF1 spectral response toward lysine, ratiometric sensing mechanisms were proposed as follows: (1) As shown in a, the measured PXRD patterns of RhB@MOF1 after the detection process match well with the theoretical one simulated based on single crystal X-ray diffraction data, implying RhB@MOF1 was stable in the detection process. (2) In this work, there was overlap between fluorescent emission of MOF1 and the absorption spectrum of RhB (b, a). The result was also verified by the higher fluorescence lifetime and enhanced emission state of RhB@MOF1 (from 1.89 ns for MOF1 to 1.94 ns for RhB@MOF1, excited at 290 nm; Table S3). Similar results were also observed in Yan’s previous work; there exist energy transfers between MR (Congo red) and Eu-MOFs. The strong fluorescence emission of MR relies on efficient energy transfer form Eu-MOFs to MR by the change of fluorescence lifetime. As mentioned above, there should exist efficient energy transfer between RhB and MOF1 in RhB@MOF1. Therefore, the strong dual fluorescence emissions of RhB@MOF1 can be observed while the simple mixture of RhB and MOF1’s spectrum can only show MOF1’s emission peak. (3) In comparison with other amino acids, lysine possesses more electron-donating amino groups than other animo acids (Figure S10) and reveals alkaline. According to the previous literature, RhB has nonfluorescent changing under neutral or alkaline pH conditions because of its spirocyclic structure. Therefore, when the alkaline lysine was added into RhB solution, it almost had no impact on RhB emission (Figure S11). On the other hand, the electron clouds of excess electron-donating amino groups in lysine can interact with the conjugate neutrons in the coordination frameworks to reduce the energy, increase the electron delocalization effect, and affect the fluorescence emission of MOF1. Similar results were also observed in previous literature. Wang et al. use glutathione stabilized gold nanoclusters (GSH-AuNCs) as the ratiometric fluorescent sensor to detect lysine by turn-on system. Special terminal 6-primary amino functional groups of lysine are the key to its generation of fluorescent centers and chromophores. As discussed above, for a ratiometric sensing mechanism, lysine can affect the photoluminescent emission of MOF1, which also further affects the RhB emission in RhB@MOF1 based on FRET (Fluorescence Resonance Energy Transfer) and forms the ratiometric fluorescent probe of RhB@MOF1 toward lysine. (4) It is noteworthy that the K sv value of d-lysine is much higher than that of l-lysine. A possible hypothesis should be that there are different chiral steric hindrances between l-,d-lysine and RhB@MOF1. FRET should be directly correlated with the steric hindrance between the acceptor and donor; when the steric hindrance becomes higher, the FRET transfer property may become worse. According to the above-mentioned analysis, the sensing mechanism for RhB@MOF1 toward lysine should be ascribed to the coefficient effect of FRET.

Sensing Mechanism for RhB@MOF1 toward Lysine

On the basis of the above RhB@MOF1 spectral response toward lysine, ratiometric sensing mechanisms were proposed as follows: (1) As shown in a, the measured PXRD patterns of RhB@MOF1 after the detection process match well with the theoretical one simulated based on single crystal X-ray diffraction data, implying RhB@MOF1 was stable in the detection process. (2) In this work, there was overlap between fluorescent emission of MOF1 and the absorption spectrum of RhB (b, a). The result was also verified by the higher fluorescence lifetime and enhanced emission state of RhB@MOF1 (from 1.89 ns for MOF1 to 1.94 ns for RhB@MOF1, excited at 290 nm; Table S3). Similar results were also observed in Yan's previous work; there exist energy transfers between MR (Congo red) and Eu-MOFs. The strong fluorescence emission of MR relies on efficient energy transfer form Eu-MOFs to MR by the change of fluorescence lifetime. As mentioned above, there should exist efficient energy transfer between RhB and MOF1 in RhB@MOF1. Therefore, the strong dual fluorescence emissions of RhB@MOF1 can be observed while the simple mixture of RhB and MOF1's spectrum can only show MOF1's emission peak. (3) In comparison with other amino acids, lysine possesses more electron-donating amino groups than other animo acids (Figure S10) and reveals alkaline. According to the previous literature, RhB has nonfluorescent changing under neutral or alkaline pH conditions because of its spirocyclic structure. Therefore, when the alkaline lysine was added into RhB solution, it almost had no impact on RhB emission (Figure S11). On the other hand, the electron clouds of excess electron-donating amino groups in lysine can interact with the conjugate neutrons in the coordination frameworks to reduce the energy, increase the electron delocalization effect, and affect the fluorescence emission of MOF1. Similar results were also observed in previous literature. Wang et al. use glutathione stabilized gold nanoclusters (GSH-AuNCs) as the ratiometric fluorescent sensor to detect lysine by turn-on system. Special terminal 6-primary amino functional groups of lysine are the key to its generation of fluorescent centers and chromophores. As discussed above, for a ratiometric sensing mechanism, lysine can affect the photoluminescent emission of MOF1, which also further affects the RhB emission in RhB@MOF1 based on FRET (Fluorescence Resonance Energy Transfer) and forms the ratiometric fluorescent probe of RhB@MOF1 toward lysine. (4) It is noteworthy that the K sv value of d-lysine is much higher than that of l-lysine. A possible hypothesis should be that there are different chiral steric hindrances between l-,d-lysine and RhB@MOF1. FRET should be directly correlated with the steric hindrance between the acceptor and donor; when the steric hindrance becomes higher, the FRET transfer property may become worse. According to the above-mentioned analysis, the sensing mechanism for RhB@MOF1 toward lysine should be ascribed to the coefficient effect of FRET.

elements.content: In comparison with the convenient detection strategies (such as gold nanoparticles, single-walled carbon nanotubes, graphene oxide, carbon nanoparticles, and fluorescent dye-labeled aptamers/GO (graphene oxide), et al.), metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have unique advantages such as controllable size and porosity, structural diversity, and controlled active sites. These luminescent MOFs-based sensors can recognize/bind events with guest substrates, have enabled MOFs to be excellent candidates as fluorescence detection platform. In the MOFs-based detection platform for insulin, aptamers (single-stranded DNA) can be used to recognize and bind insulin through hydrogen-bond reactions (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text:
MOF2 Used As a Sensing Platform for Insulin Detection and Al3+ 

In comparison with the convenient detection strategies (such as gold nanoparticles, single-walled carbon nanotubes, graphene oxide, carbon nanoparticles, and fluorescent dye-labeled aptamers/GO (graphene oxide), et al.), metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have unique advantages such as controllable size and porosity, structural diversity, and controlled active sites. These luminescent MOFs-based sensors can recognize/bind events with guest substrates, have enabled MOFs to be excellent candidates as fluorescence detection platform. In the MOFs-based detection platform for insulin, aptamers (single-stranded DNA) can be used to recognize and bind insulin through hydrogen-bond reactions (Figure S12).

elements.content: In this work, sample MOF2 (10 mg) was grounded and ultrasonicated in Tris-HCl buffer solution (pH = 7.4, 9 mL) for 5 min to prepare the suspension. Then, the suspension was added into normal human serum (1 mL) to form a 0.1 g/L suspension, which also can simulate insulin detection in a human blood environment. When 83 nM insulin-ampter single chain DNA with FAM-labeled (FAM-P, Tris-HCl as buffer solution) was injected into MOF2’s suspension (0.1 g/L, 3 mL), the fluorescence intensity gradually decreased; after 15 min, the quenching efficiency was 30.7% (a). Further after adding insulin (1.86 μM, Tris-HCl buffer solution), FAM-P was quenched more obviously; the quenching deficiency increased to 46%. When the same amount of insulin solution was injected into the solutions only containing FAM-P, the quenching deficiency was just 20.6%.

elements.content: When different concentrations of insulin buffer solution were added into a suspension containing MOF2 and FAM-P, the corresponding CIE coordinates of each emission profile further become green (c). A linear relationship between insulin concentration and FAM-P’s intensity can be obtained with the Stern–Volmer equation I 0/I = 1 + K sv·[A]. An excellent linear relationship between intensity and insulin concentration is observed (R 2 = 0.99892). K sv was 2.99 × 105 [M]−1 for 2 (), and using the equation, LOD = 3S 0/S (S 0 is the standard deviation for the blank, S is the slope of calibration curve), the detection limit for insulin should be 0.0012 μM, which reveals higher sensitivity than these previously reported MOFs-based platforms. These results indicated that MOF2 can be used as a sensing platform for detecting insulin (Ins). Then other human protein hormones such as corticotropin releasing factor (CRF), parathyroid hormone (PTH), and recombination human growth hormone (rHGH) were added into suspensions, respectively. Only insulin can have an excellent quenching effect toward the aptamer (b), which indicates highly selective detection.

elements.content: According to the previous report, aluminum is a kind of microelement that exists widely in the human body. Some studies have shown that excessive aluminum content in the body can lead to various diseases through cellular immunity, neuroendocrine and other mechanisms. Aluminum poisoning is directly related to changes in pancreatic islet cell function and glucose metabolism disorders, so it is necessary to detect Al3+ in serum solution containing insulin.

elements.content: In this work, 83 nM FAM-P, 1.72 μM insulin, and samples of 2 (0.1 g/L, 3 mL, Tris-HCl as solvent) were mixed with serum solution (10 μL) to form a samples solution. To investigate 2 as a sensing platform for the detection of metal ions in the insulin and serum solutions, including Cu2+, Ca2+, Cd2+, Al3+, NH4 +, K+, Fe3+, Co2+, and Zn2+ (as their Cl– salt form). Sample solutions (0.1 g/L, 3 mL) were titrated with various aqueous solutions (1 μM) containing different metal ions. It was worthy that FAM-P’s emissions were largely dependent on the addition of metal ions (); only Al3+ led to a significant quenching effect toward FAM-P. After the addition of 1 μM Al3+ solution, the luminescence intensity of FAM-P at 523 nm was quenched completely. The quenching effect was 89.1%, while the luminescence intensity of FAM-P cannot be influenced by other metal solutions. The quenching effect was calculated based on the equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv·[A] (1)). It exhibits an excellent linear relation between photoluminescent intensity and Al3+ concentration (R 2 = 0.98162); the K sv value was 2.7 × 107 [M]−1 at a low concentration (), which confirms MOF2 can be used as a sensing platform for selectively detecting Al3+ in the serum solution. After every 10 s, the fluorescence intensity of FAM-P decreases slightly compared to the initial fluorescent intensity (emission at 500 nm), indicating that the FAM-P can detect in real time Al3+ under sensing platform 2 (Figure S9b).

elements.content: In order to understand the origin of MOF2 sensing performance toward insulin and Al3+, a possible mechanism was investigated: (1) PXRD experimental patterns were consistent with the theoretical one, indicating that MOF2 was stable in detection progress. (2) The UV–vis spectrum demonstrated that the absorption band of 2 was not located at the emission wavelength of FAM-P (Figure S13). Because there was no spectral overlap between the emission of FAM-P and the adsorption of 2, the FRET was thus not the rational reason for the quenching mechanism. (3) As for the detection of insulin, according to previous literature, P has no fluorescent chromophores itself, while emission centered at FAM-labeled P (FAM-P) was located at 525 nm. Insulin can specifically bind with FAM-P through hydrogen bonds, which had a quenching effect in the fluorescence spectrum. Further it is noted that the zeta potentials of MOF2, P, and insulin were −0.883, −2.09, and 0.421 mV, respectively. After MOF2 was mixed with insulin and FAM-P, the zeta potential was −3.68 mV, implying that MOF2 has electrostatic interactions with insulin and FAM-P in the detection process (). (4) FAM-P can be observed to be wrapped outside of the nanoparticles through TEM (transmission electron microscope) images. These images indicate that FAM-P may combine with 2 through the electrostatic interactions on the surface of 2 (). (5) As shown in , FT-IR spectra displayed characteristic absorption bands around 3400 cm–1 for the DMF acylamino group in MOF2. When Al3+ was added into the reaction system containing MOF2, FAM-P, and insulin, the characteristic absorption bands gradually became red-shifted, absorption intensity became stronger, the result should have been attributed to the N–H and O–H bond lengths becoming longer because the acylamino group’s vbrational dipole distance became larger. Therefore, hydrogen-bond interactions can occur in MOF2’s surface, FAM-P, and Al3+, which will result in a further quenching effect in the detection process of Al3+. These results somewhat resembled the recent report utilizing MIL-101 nanoparticles as a fluorescence DNA platform, which led to a further quenching effect. El-Safty’s previous work also indicated that Al3+ can lead to a further, stronger hydrogen-bond interaction with insulin.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Quenching Mechanism toward the Detection of Insulin and Al3+ 

In order to understand the origin of MOF2 sensing performance toward insulin and Al3+, a possible mechanism was investigated: (1) PXRD experimental patterns were consistent with the theoretical one, indicating that MOF2 was stable in detection progress. (2) The UV-vis spectrum demonstrated that the absorption band of 2 was not located at the emission wavelength of FAM-P (Figure S13). Because there was no spectral overlap between the emission of FAM-P and the adsorption of 2, the FRET was thus not the rational reason for the quenching mechanism. (3) As for the detection of insulin, according to previous literature, P has no fluorescent chromophores itself, while emission centered at FAM-labeled P (FAM-P) was located at 525 nm. Insulin can specifically bind with FAM-P through hydrogen bonds, which had a quenching effect in the fluorescence spectrum. Further it is noted that the zeta potentials of MOF2, P, and insulin were -0.883, -2.09, and 0.421 mV, respectively. After MOF2 was mixed with insulin and FAM-P, the zeta potential was -3.68 mV, implying that MOF2 has electrostatic interactions with insulin and FAM-P in the detection process (). (4) FAM-P can be observed to be wrapped outside of the nanoparticles through TEM (transmission electron microscope) images. These images indicate that FAM-P may combine with 2 through the electrostatic interactions on the surface of 2 (). (5) As shown in , FT-IR spectra displayed characteristic absorption bands around 3400 cm-1 for the DMF acylamino group in MOF2. When Al3+ was added into the reaction system containing MOF2, FAM-P, and insulin, the characteristic absorption bands gradually became red-shifted, absorption intensity became stronger, the result should have been attributed to the N-H and O-H bond lengths becoming longer because the acylamino group's vbrational dipole distance became larger. Therefore, hydrogen-bond interactions can occur in MOF2's surface, FAM-P, and Al3+, which will result in a further quenching effect in the detection process of Al3+. These results somewhat resembled the recent report utilizing MIL-101 nanoparticles as a fluorescence DNA platform, which led to a further quenching effect. El-Safty's previous work also indicated that Al3+ can lead to a further, stronger hydrogen-bond interaction with insulin.

elements.content: In this work, under hydrothermal conditions, five lanthanide metal–organic frameworks have been isolated. MOF1 also can be isolated by the ultrasound method, combined with the excellent luminescence performance of Rhodamine B (RhB) to form real-time ratiometric fluorescent sensor RhB@MOF1 deliberately. On the basis of its luminescence properties, we have, for the first time, demonstrated that it is a ratiometric fluorescent sensor for the detection of lysine. In addition, with a low detection limit, MOF2 was the first example to be utilized as an excellent MOFs-based sensing platform to detect insulin and Al3+ in the human serum solution. Besides these, MOF1 and 2 also have been characterized by variable temperature direct current magnetic susceptibility measurement showing that 1 and 2 have weak antiferromagnetic interactions. This work proves the coordination framework-based photoluminescent sensor and sensing platform are sensitive to relevant environmental species such as diverse biological small molecules and protein molecules etc., which may be helpful under realistic conditions in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion and Prospection

In this work, under hydrothermal conditions, five lanthanide metal-organic frameworks have been isolated. MOF1 also can be isolated by the ultrasound method, combined with the excellent luminescence performance of Rhodamine B (RhB) to form real-time ratiometric fluorescent sensor RhB@MOF1 deliberately. On the basis of its luminescence properties, we have, for the first time, demonstrated that it is a ratiometric fluorescent sensor for the detection of lysine. In addition, with a low detection limit, MOF2 was the first example to be utilized as an excellent MOFs-based sensing platform to detect insulin and Al3+ in the human serum solution. Besides these, MOF1 and 2 also have been characterized by variable temperature direct current magnetic susceptibility measurement showing that 1 and 2 have weak antiferromagnetic interactions. This work proves the coordination framework-based photoluminescent sensor and sensing platform are sensitive to relevant environmental species such as diverse biological small molecules and protein molecules etc., which may be helpful under realistic conditions in the future.

FAM-P: 5′-GGTGGTGGGG­GGGGTTGGTA­GGGTGTCTTC-3′-FAM

Experimental SectionPreparation of [Dy­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of dysprosium acetate (25.7 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added into the mixture of DMF (4 mL) and H2O (2 mL). The mixed solutions were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon reactor; after the reaction mixture had been heated at 120 °C for 3 days and then cooled to ambient temperature after 20 h, colorless bulky crystals of 1 were isolated in 64% yield based on the H3L ligand. Elemental analysis found (%) for C24H20DyNO8: C, 46.6; H, 3.16; N, 1.98. Calcd: C, 47.03; H, 3.29; N, 2.28. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3401 (w), 1669 (s), 1628 (m), 1585 (w), 1534 (m), 1418 (m), 1382 (w), 1299 (w), and 780 (w).

Preparation of {[Gd­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A synthetic experimental detail similar to that used for 1 was employed, except for the ulitization of gadolinium acetate (51.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) instead. The colorless bulky crystals were washed five times with water. 2 was isolated in 57% yield based on H3L. Elemental analysis found (%) for C27H40GdN2O15.50: C, 39.89; H, 4.85; N, 3.02. Calcd: C, 40.64; H, 5.05; N, 2.81. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3420 (w), 1661 (s), 1624 (m), 1583 (s), 1532 (m), 1416 (s), 1381 (s), 1104 (w), and 782 (w).

Preparation of {[Ho­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]·0.5DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A synthetic experiment detail similar to that used for 1 was adopted, except the ulitization of holmium chloride (19 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) instead. The colorless bulky crystals were washed five times with water. 3 was isolated in 46% yield based on H3L. Elemental analysis found (%) for C25.5H23.5HoN1.5O8.5: C, 46.55; H, 3.15; N, 3.07; calcd: C, 46.98; H, 3.63; N, 3.22. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3376 (w), 1661 (s), 1587 (s), 1537 (m), 1416 (s), 1382 (s), 946 (w), 780 (m) and 714 (w).

Preparation of {[Pr­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]·0.5DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A synthetic experimental detail similar to that used for 1 was adopted, except the ulitization of praseodymium acetate (21.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) instead. The colorless bulky crystals were washed five times with water. 4 was isolated in 49% yield based on H3L. Elemental analysis found (%) for C25.5H37.5N1.5O15.5Pr: C, 39.65; H, 4.81; N, 2.68. Calcd: C, 40.62; H, 5.01; N, 2.79. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3553 (w), 1662 (s), 1622 (s), 1581 (m), 1529 (s), 1412 (s), 1373 (s), 760 (m), and 513 (w).

Preparation of {[Sm­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>1.55</sub>(DMF)<sub>0.45</sub>]·DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

A synthetic experimental detail similar to that used for 1 was adopted, except for the ulitization of samarium chloride (51.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H3L (18.1 mg, 0.05 mmol) instead. The colorless bulky crystals were washed five times with water. 5 was isolated in 45% yield based on H3L. Elemental analysis found (%) for C22.35H17.25N0.45O8Sm: C, 46.45; H, 2.85; N, 0.89. Calcd: C, 47.06; H, 3.05; N, 1.11. FT-IR data (cm–1): 3420 (m), 1661(s), 1629 (s), 1582 (s), 1530 (s), 1414 (s), 1253 (w), 1105 (w), 852 (w), 781 (s), 716 (w), 678 (w), 656 (w).

Preparation of [Dy­(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMF)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>) in Sonochemical Process

A mixture of dysprosium acetate (414 mg, 1 mmol) and H3L (256 mg, 1 mmol) was added into the mixture of DMF (40 mL) and H2O (20 mL). The resulting mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath for 80 min and under 100 W of power. The resulting precipitates were washed with DMF and H2O three times. Sample 1 was isolated in 52% yield based on H3L yield. Elemental analysis found (%) for C24H20DyNO8: C, 45.6; H, 2.96; N, 1.98. Calcd: C, 47.03; H, 3.29; N, 2.28.

Preparation of RhB@MOF1

In this work, 2 mg of MOF1 prepared under ultrasonic conditions (100 W, 80 min, 1 mM) was added into 10 mL of 20 mg/L RhB water solution. The resulting mixed solutions were stirred for 30 mintues and then heated to 60 °C in 24 h; then they were cooled down to ambient temperature. The solid samples can be obtained by centrifugation for 10 min at 8000 rpm, extensive washing with DMF three times, and then removal of the liquid supernatant and vacuum drying.

cln_elements.content:
PXRD patterns of MOFs 1–5 are also determined at ambient temperature to measure the sample’s phase purity. Most peak positions in simulated and experimental patterns are consistent with each other. The intensity dissimilarities may be correlated with the preferred orientation of crystalline powder samples (). The thermogravimetric decay analysis (TGA) curve of MOFs 1–5 also has been recorded (Figure S1). The weight losses of MOFs 1–5 material ranging from 30 to 200 °C are 14.66 wt %, 23 wt %, 19.01 wt %, 17.03 wt %, and 18.9 wt %, respectively, which should be attributed to the weight loss for coordination water, free DMF, and coordination DMF molecules. These results can be in good agreement with the calculated values (14.86 wt %, 22.6 wt %, 20.7 wt %, 17.8 wt %, 18.1 wt %, respectively).

MOF1 (29.78 mg ground samples) has been investigated by variable temperature (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibility, with an applied DC field of 1000 Oe. For MOF1 at 300 K, the χM T value was 12.84 cm3 K mol–1 (Figure S2a). The observed χM T value is slightly lower than the expected theotetrical value (χM T = 14.17 cm3 K mol–1), which may be ascribed to the combined effect of magnetic anisotropy, intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction, dipolar interaction, etc. When the temperature decreases, the χM T value gradually decreases to 10.75 cm3K mol–1 at 20 K, and then decreases to a value of 9.33 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. These features indicate the presence of weak antiferro-magnetic interactions between neighboring Dy­(III) ions. According to the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ), the linear fit gave values of C = 12.85 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −3.98 K, where C and θ are the Curie constant and the Weiss temperature, respectively.

Variable temperature (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibility experiments were also determined on the polycrystalline samples of MOF2. The χM T values at room temperature are slightly larger than the theoretical χM T values (7.88 cm3 K mol–1). When the temperature decreases, the χM T value gradually decreases to 7.79 cm3 mol–1 K at 20 K and then sharply decreases to 7.11 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K (Figure S2b). This phenomenon also can be correlated with the large unquenched orbital angular momentum of Gd3+. According to the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), gave values of C = 8.38 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −1.95 K, where C and θ are the Curie constant and the Weiss temperature, respectively. The θ value also represents the presence of weak antiferro-magnetic interaction between GdIII ions. There were weak magnetic interactions in multinuclear MOFs 1 and 2, which should be attributed to the shielding effects of the outer 5d and 6s shells to the inner contracted 4f orbitals.

The as-synthesized PXRD patterns of RhB@MOF1 and as-simulated theoretical PXRD ones were in good agreement, indicating that the structure of the framework remains unchanged when RhB is introduced into the coordination framework 1. Thermogravimetric decay analysis (TGA) curves of MOF1 and RhB@MOF1 are also recorded (c). The weight loss of material MOF1 ranging from 30 to 200 °C is 14.66 wt %, which should be attributed to coordinated water and DMF’s evaporation. The result can be good agreement with the calculated value (14.86 wt %). However, for the thermal cure of RhB@MOF1, the weight loss of RhB@MOF1 in the range of 30 to 200 °C is slightly lower than that of MOF1; the result may be ascribed to DMF and water molecules being partially replaced by RhB in RhB@MOF1.
